en.html: Decreasing function: as the value of \( x \) increases, the function value decreases.

en.latex: Determine the equation of the parabola.
en.html: Determine the equation of the parabola.

en.latex:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Let } y = ax^{2} \\&
\text{Substitute } P(1;-3): \quad -3 = a(1)^{2} \\&
\therefore a = -3 \\&
\therefore f(x) = -3x^{2} \quad (x \geq 0) \end{align} \)
en.html:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Let } y = ax^{2} \\&
\text{Substitute } P(1;-3): \quad -3 = a(1)^{2} \\&
\therefore a = -3 \\&
\therefore f(x) = -3x^{2} \quad (x \geq 0) \end{align} \)

en.latex: State the domain and range of \( f \) .
en.html: State the domain and range of \( f \) .

en.latex: Give the coordinates of the point on \( f^{-1} \) that is symmetrical to the point \( P \) about the line \( y=x \) .
en.html: Give the coordinates of the point on \( f^{-1} \) that is symmetrical to the point \( P \) about the line \( y=x \) .

en.latex:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Let } y = -3x^{2} \qquad (x \geq 0) \\&
\text{Interchange } x \text{ and } y: \quad x = -3y^{2} \qquad (y \geq 0) \\&
-\frac{1}{3}x = y^{2} \\&
y = \sqrt{-\frac{1}{3}x} \qquad (x \leq 0,y \geq 0) \\&
\\&
\therefore f^{-1}(x) = \sqrt{-\frac{1}{3}x} \qquad (x \leq 0) \end{align} \)
en.html:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Let } y = -3x^{2} \qquad (x \geq 0) \\&
\text{Interchange } x \text{ and } y: \quad x = -3y^{2} \qquad (y \geq 0) \\&
-\frac{1}{3}x = y^{2} \\&
y = \sqrt{-\frac{1}{3}x} \qquad (x \leq 0,y \geq 0) \\&
\\&
\therefore f^{-1}(x) = \sqrt{-\frac{1}{3}x} \qquad (x \leq 0) \end{align} \)

en.latex: State the domain and range of \( f^{-1} \) .
en.html: State the domain and range of \( f^{-1} \) .

en.latex: Determine the values of \( a \) , \( c \) and \( m \) .
en.html: Determine the values of \( a \) , \( c \) and \( m \) .

en.latex:
From the graph we see that the straight line passes through the origin, therefore \( c=0 \) .

\( \begin{align} & g(x) = mx \\&
\text{Substitute } P(4;-1): -1 = 4m \\&
\therefore m = - \frac{1}{4} \\&
\therefore g(x) = - \frac{1}{4} x \\&
\\&
f^{-1}(x) = a \sqrt{x} \\&
\text{Substitute } P(4;-1): -1 = a \sqrt{4} \\&
-1 = 2a \\&
\therefore a = - \frac{1}{2} \\&
\therefore f^{-1}(x) = - \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{x} \end{align} \)
en.html:
From the graph we see that the straight line passes through the origin, therefore \( c=0 \) .

\( \begin{align} & g(x) = mx \\&
\text{Substitute } P(4;-1): -1 = 4m \\&
\therefore m = - \frac{1}{4} \\&
\therefore g(x) = - \frac{1}{4} x \\&
\\&
f^{-1}(x) = a \sqrt{x} \\&
\text{Substitute } P(4;-1): -1 = a \sqrt{4} \\&
-1 = 2a \\&
\therefore a = - \frac{1}{2} \\&
\therefore f^{-1}(x) = - \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{x} \end{align} \)

en.latex: Give the domain and range of \( f^{-1} \) and \( g \) .
en.html: Give the domain and range of \( f^{-1} \) and \( g \) .

en.latex:
\( \begin{align} & g: \qquad \text{Domain: } x \in \mathbb{R} \quad \text{Range: } y \in \mathbb{R} \\&
f^{-1}: \qquad \text{Domain: } x \geq 0 \quad \text{Range: } y \leq 0 \end{align} \)
en.html:
\( \begin{align} & g: \qquad \text{Domain: } x \in \mathbb{R} \quad \text{Range: } y \in \mathbb{R} \\&
f^{-1}: \qquad \text{Domain: } x \geq 0 \quad \text{Range: } y \leq 0 \end{align} \)

en.latex: For which values of \( x \) is \( g(x) < f(x) \) ?
en.html: For which values of \( x \) is \( g(x) < f(x) \) ?

en.latex:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Let } y = - \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{x} \\&
\text{Interchange } x \text{ and } y: \\&
\quad x = - \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{y} \qquad (y \geq 0) \\&
-2x = \sqrt{y} \\&
\therefore y = 4x^{2} \qquad (y \geq 0) \end{align} \)
en.html:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Let } y = - \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{x} \\&
\text{Interchange } x \text{ and } y: \\&
\quad x = - \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{y} \qquad (y \geq 0) \\&
-2x = \sqrt{y} \\&
\therefore y = 4x^{2} \qquad (y \geq 0) \end{align} \)

en.latex: Determine the coordinates of the point(s) of intersection of \( g \) and \( f \) .
en.html: Determine the coordinates of the point(s) of intersection of \( g \) and \( f \) .

en.latex:
To determine the coordinates of the point(s) of intersection, we equate \( g \) and \( f \) :

\( \begin{align} & - \frac{1}{4} x = 4x^{2} \\&
0 = 4x^{2} + \frac{1}{4} x \\&
0 = x \left(4x + \frac{1}{4} \right) \\&
\therefore x = 0 \text{ or } 4x + \frac{1}{4} = 0 \\&
\text{If } x = 0: y = 0 \\&
\text{If } 4x + \frac{1}{4} = 0: \\&
4x = - \frac{1}{4} \\&
x = - \frac{1}{16} \\&
\text{If } x = - \frac{1}{16}: y = - \frac{1}{4} \left( - \frac{1}{16} \right) \\&
= \frac{1}{64} \end{align} \)

Therefore, the two graphs intersect at \( (0;0) \) and \( \left( - \frac{1}{16}; \frac{1}{64} \right) \)
en.html:
To determine the coordinates of the point(s) of intersection, we equate \( g \) and \( f \) :

\( \begin{align} & - \frac{1}{4} x = 4x^{2} \\&
0 = 4x^{2} + \frac{1}{4} x \\&
0 = x \left(4x + \frac{1}{4} \right) \\&
\therefore x = 0 \text{ or } 4x + \frac{1}{4} = 0 \\&
\text{If } x = 0: y = 0 \\&
\text{If } 4x + \frac{1}{4} = 0: \\&
4x = - \frac{1}{4} \\&
x = - \frac{1}{16} \\&
\text{If } x = - \frac{1}{16}: y = - \frac{1}{4} \left( - \frac{1}{16} \right) \\&
= \frac{1}{64} \end{align} \)

Therefore, the two graphs intersect at \( (0;0) \) and \( \left( - \frac{1}{16}; \frac{1}{64} \right) \)

en.latex: Is \( f \) an increasing or decreasing function?
en.html: Is \( f \) an increasing or decreasing function?

en.latex: Decreasing function: as the value of \( x \) increases, the function value decreases.
en.html: Decreasing function: as the value of \( x \) increases, the function value decreases.

en.latex:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Let } y = \frac{5}{2}x^{2} \qquad (x \geq 0) \\&
\text{Interchange } x \text{ and } y: \\
\quad x &= \frac{5}{2}y^{2} \qquad (y \geq 0) \\
\frac{2}{5}x &= y^{2} \\
y &= \sqrt{\frac{2}{5}x} \qquad (x \ge 0, y \geq 0) \\
\therefore g^{-1}(x)& = \sqrt{\frac{2}{5}x} \qquad (x \geq 0) \end{align} \)
en.html:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Let } y = \frac{5}{2}x^{2} \qquad (x \geq 0) \\&
\text{Interchange } x \text{ and } y: \\
\quad x &= \frac{5}{2}y^{2} \qquad (y \geq 0) \\
\frac{2}{5}x &= y^{2} \\
y &= \sqrt{\frac{2}{5}x} \qquad (x \ge 0, y \geq 0) \\
\therefore g^{-1}(x)& = \sqrt{\frac{2}{5}x} \qquad (x \geq 0) \end{align} \)

en.latex: Calculate the point(s) where \( g \) and \( g^{-1} \) intersect.
en.html: Calculate the point(s) where \( g \) and \( g^{-1} \) intersect.

en.latex:
\( \begin{align} &\frac{5}{2}x^{2} = \sqrt{\frac{2}{5}x} \\&
\left( \frac{5}{2}x^{2} \right)^{2} = \left( \sqrt{\frac{2}{5}x} \right)^{2} \\&
\frac{25}{4}x^{4} = \frac{2}{5}x \\&
\frac{25}{4}x^{4} - \frac{2}{5}x = 0 \\&
125x^{4} - 8x = 0 \\&
x(125x^{3} - 8) = 0 \\&
x(5x - 2)(25x^{2} +10x + 4) = 0 \\&
\therefore x = 0 \text{ or } 5x - 2 = 0 \text{ or } 25x^{2} +10x + 4 = 0 \\&
\text{If } x=0, \quad y = 0 \\&
\text{If } x = \frac{2}{5}, \quad y = \frac{5}{2} \left( \frac{2}{5} \right) ^{2} \\&
\therefore y = \frac{2}{5} \\&
\text{If } 25x^{2} +10x + 4 =0 \\&
\text{Use quadratic formula: } \quad x = \frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{100 - 4(25)(4)}}{2(25)}\\&
= \frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{-300}}{50} \\&
\therefore \text{no real solution} \end{align} \)

Therefore, the points of intersection are \( (0;0) \) and \( \left( \frac{2}{5};\frac{2}{5} \right) \) .
en.html:
\( \begin{align} &\frac{5}{2}x^{2} = \sqrt{\frac{2}{5}x} \\&
\left( \frac{5}{2}x^{2} \right)^{2} = \left( \sqrt{\frac{2}{5}x} \right)^{2} \\&
\frac{25}{4}x^{4} = \frac{2}{5}x \\&
\frac{25}{4}x^{4} - \frac{2}{5}x = 0 \\&
125x^{4} - 8x = 0 \\&
x(125x^{3} - 8) = 0 \\&
x(5x - 2)(25x^{2} +10x + 4) = 0 \\&
\therefore x = 0 \text{ or } 5x - 2 = 0 \text{ or } 25x^{2} +10x + 4 = 0 \\&
\text{If } x=0, \quad y = 0 \\&
\text{If } x = \frac{2}{5}, \quad y = \frac{5}{2} \left( \frac{2}{5} \right) ^{2} \\&
\therefore y = \frac{2}{5} \\&
\text{If } 25x^{2} +10x + 4 =0 \\&
\text{Use quadratic formula: } \quad x = \frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{100 - 4(25)(4)}}{2(25)}\\&
= \frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{-300}}{50} \\&
\therefore \text{no real solution} \end{align} \)

Therefore, the points of intersection are \( (0;0) \) and \( \left( \frac{2}{5};\frac{2}{5} \right) \) .

en.latex: Sketch the graphs of \( g(x) \) and \( g^{-1}(x) \) on the same set of axes. Indicate the point of intersection. Also draw in the line \( y=x \) .
en.html: Sketch the graphs of \( g(x) \) and \( g^{-1}(x) \) on the same set of axes. Indicate the point of intersection. Also draw in the line \( y=x \) .

en.latex: Use the sketch to determine if \( g(x) \) and \( g^{-1}(x) \) are increasing or decreasing functions.
en.html: Use the sketch to determine if \( g(x) \) and \( g^{-1}(x) \) are increasing or decreasing functions.

en.latex:
\( \begin{align} &g: \text{as } x \text{ increases, } y \text{ also increases, } \therefore g \text{ is an increasing function. } \\&
g^{-1}: \text{as } x \text{ increases, } y \text{ also increases, } \therefore g^{-1} \text{ is an increasing function. } \end{align} \)
en.html:
\( \begin{align} &g: \text{as } x \text{ increases, } y \text{ also increases, } \therefore g \text{ is an increasing function. } \\&
g^{-1}: \text{as } x \text{ increases, } y \text{ also increases, } \therefore g^{-1} \text{ is an increasing function. } \end{align} \)

en.html: Calculate the average gradient of \( g^{-1} \) between the two points of intersection.

en.latex: Sketch the graphs of \( f(x) \) and \( f^{-1}(x) \) on the same set of axes. Indicate the point of intersection. Also draw in the line \( y=x \) .

en.latex: Is the graph of \( f^{-1}(x) \) a function? Give a reason for your answer.
en.html: Is the graph of \( f^{-1}(x) \) a function? Give a reason for your answer.

en.latex: No, because it is a one-to-many function. For every \( x \) -values, there is more than one \( y \) -value. \( \therefore \) a relation.
en.html: No, because it is a one-to-many function. For every \( x \) -values, there is more than one \( y \) -value. \( \therefore \) a relation.

en.latex: Restrict the graph of \( f(x) \) in one specific way so that the inverse will now be a function.
en.html: Restrict the graph of \( f(x) \) in one specific way so that the inverse will now be a function.

en.latex: Hence, draw the new graph of \( f(x) \) and \( f^{-1}(x) \) on the same set of axes.
en.html: Hence, draw the new graph of \( f(x) \) and \( f^{-1}(x) \) on the same set of axes.

en.latex:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Let } y = -x^{2} - 2 \qquad (y \leq -2) \\&
\text{Interchange } x \text{ and } y: \quad \\
x &= -y^{2} - 2 \qquad (x \leq -2) \\
x + 2 &= -y^{2} \\
-x - 2 &= y^{2} \\
y &= \pm \sqrt{-x - 2} \qquad (x \leq -2) \end{align} \)
en.html:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Let } y = -x^{2} - 2 \qquad (y \leq -2) \\&
\text{Interchange } x \text{ and } y: \quad \\
x &= -y^{2} - 2 \qquad (x \leq -2) \\
x + 2 &= -y^{2} \\
-x - 2 &= y^{2} \\
y &= \pm \sqrt{-x - 2} \qquad (x \leq -2) \end{align} \)

en.latex: Sketch the inverse and discuss the characteristics of the graph.
en.html: Sketch the inverse and discuss the characteristics of the graph.

en.latex:
The inverse is a not a function. The turning point of the inverse is \( (-2;0) \) and \( x \) -intercept is \( (-2;0) \) .
\( \text{Inverse}:\)
\(\text{domain } \{x: x \leq -2, x \in \mathbb{R} \} \)
\(\text{range } \{y: y \in \mathbb{R} \} \)
en.html:
The inverse is a not a function. The turning point of the inverse is \( (-2;0) \) and \( x \) -intercept is \( (-2;0) \) .

en.latex: Determine the algebraic formula for the inverse of \( H \) .
en.html: Determine the algebraic formula for the inverse of \( H \) .

en.latex:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Let } y = x^{2} - 9 \qquad (y \geq -9) \\&
\text{Interchange } x \text{ and } y: \\
\quad x &= y^{2} - 9 \qquad (x \geq -9) \\
x + 9 &= y^{2} \\
y &= \pm \sqrt{x + 9} \qquad (x \geq -9) \end{align} \)
en.html:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Let } y = x^{2} - 9 \qquad (y \geq -9) \\&
\text{Interchange } x \text{ and } y: \\
\quad x &= y^{2} - 9 \qquad (x \geq -9) \\
x + 9 &= y^{2} \\
y &= \pm \sqrt{x + 9} \qquad (x \geq -9) \end{align} \)

en.latex: Determine the intercepts and turning points.
en.html: Determine the intercepts and turning points.

en.latex:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Let } x = 0: \\
y &= (0)^{2} - 9 \\
&= - 9 \\&
\text{Let } y = 0: \\
0 &= x^{2} - 9 \\
x^2 &= 9 \\
\therefore x& = \pm 3 \end{align} \)
The intercepts are \( (0;-9) \) and \( (-3;0) \) , \( (3;0) \) .
en.html:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Let } x = 0: \\
y &= (0)^{2} - 9 \\
&= - 9 \\&
\text{Let } y = 0: \\
0 &= x^{2} - 9 \\
x^2 &= 9 \\
\therefore x& = \pm 3 \end{align} \)
The intercepts are \( (0;-9) \) and \( (-3;0) \) , \( (3;0) \) .

af.latex:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Laat } x = 0: \\
y &= (0)^{2} - 9 \\
&= - 9 \\&
\text{Laat } y = 0: \\
0 &= x^{2} - 9 \\
x^2 &= 9 \\
\therefore x& = \pm 3 \end{align} \)
Die afsnitte is \ ((0; -9) \) en \ ((-3; 0) \), \ ((3; 0) \).
af.html:
\( \begin{align} &\text{Laat } x = 0: \\
y &= (0)^{2} - 9 \\
&= - 9 \\&
\text{Laat } y = 0: \\
0 &= x^{2} - 9 \\
x^2 &= 9 \\
\therefore x& = \pm 3 \end{align} \)
Die afsnitte is \ ((0; -9) \) en \ ((-3; 0) \), \ ((3; 0) \).

en.latex: Is the inverse a function? Give reasons.
en.html: Is the inverse a function? Give reasons.

en.latex: No. The inverse does not pass the vertical line test. It is a one-to-many relation.
en.html: No. The inverse does not pass the vertical line test. It is a one-to-many relation.

en.latex: Show algebraically and graphically the effect of restricting the domain of \( H \) to \( \{x: x \leq 0 \} \)
en.html: Show algebraically and graphically the effect of restricting the domain of \( H \) to \( \{x: x \leq 0 \} \)

en.latex:
If the domain of \( H \) is restricted to \( \{x: x \leq 0 \} \) , then the inverse is \( H^{-1}(x) = - \sqrt{x^{2} + 9} \quad (x \geq -9, y \leq 0) \)

The graph of \( H^{-1} \) cuts a vertical line only once at any one time and therefore passes the vertical line test.
en.html:
If the domain of \( H \) is restricted to \( \{x: x \leq 0 \} \) , then the inverse is \( H^{-1}(x) = - \sqrt{x^{2} + 9} \quad (x \geq -9, y \leq 0) \)

The graph of \( H^{-1} \) cuts a vertical line only once at any one time and therefore passes the vertical line test.

en.html: \(P(2;4)\) is a point on \(y={x}^{2}\). Determine the coordinates of \(Q\), the point on the graph of the inverse which is symmetrical to \(P\) about the line \(y=x\).

en.latex:
Determine the average gradient between:
the origin and \(P\);
the origin and \(Q\).
Interpret the answers.
en.html:
Determine the average gradient between:
the origin and \(P\);
the origin and \(Q\).
Interpret the answers.

en.latex:
\(\text{Average gradient for P: } = \frac{y_{P} - y_{O}}{x_{P} - x_{O}} \)
\( = \frac{ 4 - 0 }{2- 0 } \)
\( = 2 \)
\( \text{Average gradient for Q: } = \frac{y_{Q} - y_{O}}{x_{Q} - x_{O}} \)
\( = \frac{ 2 - 0 }{4- 0 } \)
\( = \frac{1}{2} \)
\( \text{Average gradient OP: } = 2 \text{ and}\)
\(\text{Average gradient OQ: } = \frac{1}{2} \)
\( \therefore \text{Both gradients are positive, and they are also reciprocals of each other.}\)
en.html:
\(\text{Average gradient for P: } = \frac{y_{P} - y_{O}}{x_{P} - x_{O}} \)
\( = \frac{ 4 - 0 }{2- 0 } \)
\( = 2 \)
\( \text{Average gradient for Q: } = \frac{y_{Q} - y_{O}}{x_{Q} - x_{O}} \)
\( = \frac{ 2 - 0 }{4- 0 } \)
\( = \frac{1}{2} \)
\( \text{Average gradient OP: } = 2 \text{ and}\)
\(\text{Average gradient OQ: } = \frac{1}{2} \)
\( \therefore \text{Both gradients are positive, and they are also reciprocals of each other.}\)

No, because it is a one-to-many function. For every \( x \) -values, there is more than one \( y \) -value. \( \therefore \) a relation.
en.html: No, because it is a one-to-many function. For every \( x \) -values, there is more than one \( y \) -value. \( \therefore \) a relation.

The inverse is a not a function. The turning point of the inverse is \( (2;0) \) and \( x \) -intercept is \( (2;0) \) .
\( \text{Inverse}: \qquad \text{domain } \{x: x \leq -2, x \in \mathbb{R} \} \quad \text{range } \{y: y \in \mathbb{R}\} \)

en.latex:
If the domain of \( H \) is restricted to \( \{x: x \leq 0 \} \) , then the inverse is \( H^{-1}(x) = - \sqrt{x^{2} + 9} \quad (x \geq -9, y \leq 0) \)

The graph of \( H^{-1} \) cuts a vertical line only once at any one time and therefore passes the vertical line test.
en.html:

en.latex: The graph of \( f(x) \) is moved \( 2 \) units up and reflected about the \( x \) -axis.
en.html: The graph of \( f(x) \) is moved \( 2 \) units up and reflected about the \( x \) -axis.

en.latex: The graph of \( f(x) \) is moved \( 2 \) units up and reflected about the \( y \) -axis.
en.html: The graph of \( f(x) \) is moved \( 2 \) units up and reflected about the \( y \) -axis.

en.latex: The graph of \( f(x) \) is moved \( 2 \) units down and reflected about the \( x \) -axis.
en.html: The graph of \( f(x) \) is moved \( 2 \) units down and reflected about the \( x \) -axis.

en.latex: The graph of \( f(x) \) is moved \( 4 \) down up and reflected about the \( y \) -axis.
en.html: The graph of \( f(x) \) is moved \( 4 \) down up and reflected about the \( y \) -axis.
